results.title: Introduction
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Instruments of the band and orchestra”.
Shows the three sections of a band - the brasses, the woodwinds, and the percussions - and explains the function of each group of instruments. Explains that the addition of a string section distinguishes an orchestra from a band. Includes demonstrations of well-known instruments from each section. Features the Jollet Township High School Band and the Youth Orchestra of Greater Chicago.

Demonstrates use in teaching of the chalkboard, flannelboard, magnetic board, charts, drawings, models, epidiascope, slide and overhead projector.

results.title: Why I.T.?
results.creator_credit: Dick Need, Great Britain. Royal Navy and Stewart Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Instructional Techniques”.
Demonstrates the need for adequate training in the complex technological environment of a large undertaking like the Royal Navy, and discusses the standard of instruction necessary.

results.title: A Class of your own (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Richard Need, John R.F. Stewart and Stewart Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Instructional Techniques”.
Primarily designed for the instruction of the services, this film puts forward principles that are equally applicable to teaching in the civilian field. The instructor must plan their lessons in advance, whether in the classroom or at the workbench. The lesson should have a proper introduction, be developed logically, and flow naturally and interestingly to its concluding summary. The value of class activity, teaching aids, planned questions and proper note-taking are all dealt with in this film. The film falls into two parts: classroom instruction and practical instruction.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Need, John R.F. Stewart and Stewart Films

results.title: The John Marsden video
results.creator_credit: Mark Waters, Christine McCaul Gleitzman and Insight Profile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Insight profile”.
Author John Marsden discusses the theories behind writing a successful novel. Using examples from his own work, he explores the different writing styles he uses in his own works, the way the characters think, and the motivating factors which make the characters come to life on the page. Also includes discussion on sentence structure, imagery, and how to select the right words to captivate the reader.

results.title: The Gary Crew video
results.creator_credit: Mark Waters, Christine McCaul Gleitzman and Insight Profile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Insight profile”.
Gary Crew explains how he developed the ideas behind his award winning novels. He takes you back through his childhood and early life to the buildings and landscapes which were the inspiration for the settings of many of his books. He explains how the right ‘setting’ for a novel is as important as a good storyline, and how to develop any place, no matter how boring, into something special.

results.title: The Libby Gleeson video
results.creator_credit: Mark Waters, Christine McCaul Gleitzman and Insight Profile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Insight profile”.
Writer Libby Gleeson talks of the inspiration behind her novels, the experiences and settings in the environment around her and how they inform the realistic nature of her fiction writing. She discusses the importance of a credible “place” and how environment has shaped the characters in her novels - decision making on how to decide on point of view and how it’s influenced by the text is also covered. The importance of research, in particular in the classroom and in the schoolyard is mentioned, as well as issues throughout her novels. A brief biographical background and the business end of publication is also provided.

results.title: The Victor Kelleher video
results.creator_credit: Mark Waters, Christine McCaul Gleitzman and Insight Profile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Insight profile”.
Noted children’s author Victor Kelleher talks frankly of how his homesickness for Africa led him to writing - “In a way I stumbled into writing. I didn’t go looking for a writing career. It found me.” He explains how a dream from his youth and a visit to the zoo with his child led to the novel “Taronga”; a relative talking of his childhood, the inspiration behind “Del-Del”. Settings also play an important role in his work as well as being a source of inspiration; the Zambezi Valley to “Papio” for example. The author explains the role of characters in his writing, where the inspiration comes from, writers block, interests and hobbies that have influenced his work (Where the whales sing, Parkland, Slow burn), and reads from various novels. A teacher’s guide accompanies the tape.
